paragraphs.name: 0f72
paragraphs.text: The website: https://countdown.ted.com
Join the COUNTDOWN — turning the tide on climate change
TED-Global launches ZERO NET Emissions by 2050 initiative

paragraphs.name: fa3f
paragraphs.text: I just spent the last couple of hours remotely linked to the launch of COUNTDOWN which took place in New York today. Over the last couple of years I had the opportunity to contribute to a few projects of Future Stewards who have now partnered with TED, Youtube and others to launch this important new initiative to build global collaboration across all sectors and among all of humanity to achieve net-zero emissions globally by 2050 through cutting emissions by half every ten years starting in 2020.

paragraphs.name: d486
paragraphs.text: “HERE’S THE PLAN

paragraphs.name: d6fd
paragraphs.text: The science is clear. The world faces climate catastrophe unless we act urgently. We must cut net greenhouse emissions from the current 55 gigatons per year to zero.

To get this done, we’ll have to ENGAGE EVERYONE. Politicians. CEOs. Investors. Media influencers. Activists. Citizens all over the world, young and old. We all have a role to play. Including you. Let’s count down greenhouse emissions. If we’re successful, it will be a countdown to a hopeful future.

paragraphs.name: b8fd
paragraphs.text: It starts with a willingness to look at the science. We have a chance to avoid climate catastrophe if we can work together, from a solid scientific mindset, to answers these five giant questions.”

paragraphs.name: 1fa6
paragraphs.text: — COUNTDOWN

I love the way they picked up on the spirit of living the questions being so central to co-creating regenerative cultures everywhere and are challenging all of us to get involved in collectively living into the answers on these:

paragraphs.name: ff22
paragraphs.text: How rapidly can we move to 100% clean energy?
How can we re-engineer the stuff that surrounds us?

paragraphs.name: 01b7
paragraphs.text: How do we transform the way we move?
How can we spark a worldwide shift to healthier food systems?

paragraphs.name: fff9
paragraphs.text: How extensively can we re-green the earth?

paragraphs.name: 0fa9
paragraphs.text: From the COUNTDOWN website

The launch event today was hosted by Christiana Figueres who is a partner in Future Stewards through Global Optimism and Chris Anderson, the curator of TED. It involved a wide range of guests all with short contributions. I had a technical glitch so I missed the first 5 minutes or so, but I assume the launch will be available for streaming soon. Check for the hashtag #JoinTheCountdown.

paragraphs.name: 6b21
paragraphs.text: Screenshot from the COUNTDOWN launch event which I followed remotely

paragraphs.name: d179
paragraphs.text: Hoesung Lee from the IPCC stressed the need for net zero emmission by 2050 this means we need to start now and half emissions by 2030 and then half again by 2040 to get to zero net emissions by mid-Century.

paragraphs.name: cd2d
paragraphs.text: Johann Rockström stressed that many of the planetary boundaries are “on the move” which is an urgent warning of the danger of going into run-away climate change. He also stressed that the science is pretty clear that it is not too late yet and that the agenda of halving emissions consistently every 10 years over the next three decades would help us to avoid the worst, ending with “science is behind you, let’s go!”

paragraphs.name: 59fb
paragraphs.text: Christiana Figueres reminded everyone that we have been talking for decades and emissions keep rising. It is time to make that turn in the curve towards reducing net global emissions now 2020 is the year to achieve the inflection. She talked about ‘Future Stewards’ and the five areas that the action plan focuses on: power, built environment, transport, food, and ecosystems regeneration.
I simply could not resist to share this amazing endorsement of my book by Christiana Figueres

paragraphs.name: e651
paragraphs.text: Christiana stressed that COUNTDOWN is something positive to get excited about as we begin to co-create and respond to the challenge of climate change creatively. “This is not about sacrefacing it is about co-creating a much better future for all of us.”

paragraphs.name: 4f62
paragraphs.text: Screenshot from the COUNTDOWN launch event which I followed remotely

paragraphs.name: 7c1f
paragraphs.text: Wanjira Maathai, daughter of Wangari Maathai the Nobel laureate who founded the Green Belt Movement, all for all of humanity to come together in the largest global reforestation force and bring back the world’s forests. Tshering Tobgay, the president of the People’s Democratic Party in Bhutan — the world’s only reportedly carbon negative country call on people to “work together to find solutions that are both powerful and just.”

paragraphs.name: cc9a
paragraphs.text: Screenshot from the COUNTDOWN launch event which I followed remotely

Hiro Mizuno, the executive managing director and chief investment officer of Japan’s $1.4 trillion Government Pension Investment Fund shared how the fund had analysed their portfolio and realized that they were supporting a path towards a 3 degree world with their investments and were committed to changing that rapidly to help “to move the needle” in the hope that others in the capital markets would do the same.

paragraphs.name: ccc9
paragraphs.text: Screenshot from the COUNTDOWN launch event which I followed remotely

paragraphs.name: d537
paragraphs.text: Four young activists were given the opportunity to explain why they decided to join the Fridays for Future movement around the world, among them Jamie Margolin from Seattle, founder of Zero Hour. A young activist from Mexico highlighted the need to “not just fix the future” but also “fix the past” and include the voice of indigenous wisdom keepers who have been ignored for far too long.

paragraphs.name: 2d49
paragraphs.text: Part of the COUNTDOWN process will be a series of countdown summits, the first of which will be held on 10.10.2020 in Bergen, Norway and bring together 1000 key people active in catalysing change around the world focused on the above named five solutions areas. In the lead up to these summit the global TEDed network will also contribute with events building up to that gathering. Dora Dzvonyar from TEDxTUM (Technical University Munich) called in and shared how exciting their local team was about organizing events that will feed into the Countdown mission.

paragraphs.name: c512
paragraphs.text: COUNTDOWN SUMMIT 2020

paragraphs.name: b41c
paragraphs.text: Some representatives of projects working on local and regional implementation of solutions in the five areas also contributed among them Wahleah Johns who helps to train people to install PV panels through Native Renewables and Anna Lappé the author of ‘Diet for a Hot planet’ who promotes shifts in the food system and regenerative agriculture projects.

paragraphs.name: 54f1
paragraphs.text: Christiana stressed multiple times that “this is about everyone” and that the campaign aimed to really involved people around the world from all sectors. She also announced the massive global media campaign that has been developed for COUNTDOWN and invited people to use the memes created in many different languages which can be downloaded on the COUNTDOWN website.

paragraphs.name: d2d3
paragraphs.text: Claire O’Neill, the incoming president of COP26 which will take place in Glasgow, joined with a video from COP25 in which she emphasized that “2020 is the year of action when we have to stop talking and make things happen.”

paragraphs.name: c7a1
paragraphs.text: Yuval Noah Harari, author of ‘Homo Deus’ spoke eloquently on how “climate change is about inequality” between people, between species in the family of life, between the attention people give to the clear message of scientists and ill intentioned spreaders of fake-news. He spoke to the need for us to ask ourselves “what kind of human do we want to be?” and reminded people that climate change is about choices: “We can create a more just world and make ourselves better people.”

paragraphs.name: ffe5
paragraphs.text: Katharine Hayhoe a climate scientist with a strong conservative background and active member of the church called on people to understand that this issue is beyond party politics and political allegiance. “Climate change is, as the military calls it, a threat multiplier” she said and since “we are all impacted by a change in climate, to care about it we only need to be human.”

paragraphs.name: 994d
paragraphs.text: Towards the end Al Gore came in remotely to suggest that “the hope is very real. We actually do have the solutions avaliable to us!” and quoted Dornbusch’s law that “things take much longer than one thought they would but then they happen much faster than anyone thought they could” and ended by saying: “Just remember, political will is itself a renewable resource!”

paragraphs.name: 9d32
paragraphs.text: Christiana stressed that “if there is one thing that we cannot fail on. It is in addressing climate change in a timely way” and thanked the coalition that is building to make sure we won’t. The core team is TED, YouTube and Future Stewards in collaboration with partner organizations like the C40, the Global Covenant of Mayors, Climate Reality Project, Climate Leadership Initiative and Project Drawdown.

paragraphs.name: 04c0
paragraphs.text: During Q & A, Joe Confino from the Huffington Post asked an important question about the role of spirituality in this transformation and Christiana answered by suggesting that the insight of the fundamental interdependence and interconnectedness of all life is shared by the worlds wisdom traditions but one does not have to regard oneself as spiritual to understand the significance of this insight.

The last question was about the importance of the role of youth and the inspiration they can provide. It was answered by Xiye Bastida, a young Mexican climate activists, who spoke powerfully about intergenerational inspiration saying that she was glad to hear that Fridays For Future and its young people had inspired the people present in the room and us remote participants but that these very people — in turn — had also inspired her generation. We are all in this together! Join the COUNTDOWN!
